title: 105_s2025
content: The Act may be cited as the "Food Research, Education, Safety, and Health Act of 1998". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, such as "committee of jurisdiction," "food," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 3. CONSUMER EDUCATION FOOD SAFETY BLOCK GRANTS. The Secretary will provide grants to States for consumer education food safety programs. States must submit an application detailing planned activities, designate an agency to administer funds, and ensure proper fund usage. Grant amounts will be allocated to each State based on available funds for the fiscal year. The Secretary will provide grants to States for consumer education food safety programs based on population proportions. Payments to approved States will be made in installments, with adjustments for overpayments or underpayments. Funds received by a State under this section shall be used for consumer education food safety programs, providing education on safe food practices at each step in the food chain. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001 to carry out the mechanisms described in subsection (g), with the Secretary having the option to require matching funds from States. The Secretary, in collaboration with various agencies, will conduct consumer education initiatives on food irradiation, focusing on ground beef and poultry. A study will be conducted on the cost and feasibility of irradiating fruits and vegetables, along with new technologies. $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001 for this purpose. Additionally, a Food Safety Council will be established. Establishment of Food Safety Council with 12 members, including the Secretary, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Commissioner of Food and Drugs. Members appointed by President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House for terms not exceeding 3 years. Secretary serves as Council chairperson. The Food Safety Council, chaired by the Secretary, meets twice a year with at least five members present. The Council evaluates food safety research, directs updates in science and technology, and submits an annual report to relevant committees. The Food Safety Council, chaired by the Secretary, meets twice a year with at least five members present. They evaluate food safety research, direct updates in science and technology, and submit an annual report to relevant committees on actions taken and recommendations for improvements in food safety. Members of the Council receive compensation based on their status as federal or nonfederal members. The Food Safety Council, chaired by the Secretary, meets twice a year with at least five members present to evaluate food safety research and make recommendations. Federal members serve without additional compensation and are allowed travel expenses. The Secretary will use up to $100,000 annually from the Department of Agriculture funds for this purpose. SEC. 6. COMPETITIVE RESEARCH GRANTS FOR REDUCING THREATS OF FOOD-BORNE PATHOGENS. The Secretary will award competitive grants for research on deadly food-borne pathogens to various institutions and individuals for up to 5 years. Participation in the grant process will involve qualified scientists from different sectors. Funds received cannot be used for building-related purposes. A report is due by December 1, 2001. The Secretary will submit a report on actions taken by December 1, 2001. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001. The Secretary will conduct demonstration projects to study food-borne pathogens and develop interventions. A report on these actions is due by December 1, 2001. Up to $100,000 from the Department of Agriculture funds will be used for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001. SEC. 8 authorizes funding for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to improve detection of food-borne pathogens and for the National Institutes of Health to research medical treatments for infected individuals. The Secretary will establish a Food Safety Research Information Office in the National Agricultural Library to provide information on food safety research initiatives. The Secretary, in collaboration with various agencies, will conduct risk assessments for animals, fruits, vegetables, and food safety practices in the United States to determine pathogen risks at different stages of the food chain. After conducting risk assessments for animals, fruits, vegetables, and food safety practices, the Secretary will establish species-specific working groups with producer groups to address potential pathogens on farms. A report on the results of the risk assessments must be submitted to the relevant committees within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 11. SAFETY AND HEALTH RISKS OF IMPORTED FOOD. $10,340,000 authorized annually from 1999 to 2001 to enhance safety of imported food through new positions for microbiologists and inspectors, and acquiring scientific equipment.
